Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the inaccuracy of COVID-19 tests, stating that they are 93% inaccurate, while the expert's verdict clarifies that the statement is taken out of context and refers to a specific type of test in certain cases.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide sufficient evidence or support to back up the assertion that COVID-19 tests are 93% inaccurate.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the statement made by Boris Johnson about the accuracy of COVID-19 tests applies universally to all tests, which is not the case.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the statement made by Boris Johnson, such as the specific context in which he was referring to a particular type of test in certain cases.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the accuracy of COVID-19 tests can vary depending on the type of test and the circumstances in which it is used.
